abstract: <jats:p>A moderately halophilic, aerobic, motile, Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium (strain LV4<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>) was isolated from saline soil around the lake Laguna Verde in the Bolivian Andes. The organism is a heterotroph, able to utilize various carbohydrates as a carbon source. It showed tryptophan deaminase, oxidase and catalase activity, but was unable to produce indole or H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>S; nitrate was not reduced. The G+C content of the genomic DNA was 56·1 mol%. The pH range for growth was 5–10, temperature range was 0–45 °C and the range of NaCl concentrations was 0–25 % (w/v). On the basis of 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, strain LV4<jats:sup>T</jats:sup> was found to be closely related to <jats:italic>Chromohalobacter canadensis</jats:italic> DSM 6769<jats:sup>T</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>Pseudomonas beijerinckii</jats:italic> DSM 7218<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>; however, its DNA–DNA relatedness with these type strains was low. Strain LV4<jats:sup>T</jats:sup> resembled other <jats:italic>Chromohalobacter</jats:italic> species with respect to various physiological, biochemical and nutritional characteristics but also exhibited differences. Thus, a novel species, <jats:italic>Chromohalobacter sarecensis</jats:italic> sp. nov., is proposed, with LV4<jats:sup>T</jats:sup> (=CCUG 47987<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>=ATCC BAA-761<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>) as the type strain.</jats:p>
title: Chromohalobacter sarecensis sp. nov., a psychrotolerant moderate halophile isolated from the saline Andean region of Bolivia
